The "Electronic Marketplace Ownership Disclosure Act" aims to address concerns about certain Internet exchanges not disclosing ownership interests and business arrangements, calling for increased consumer protections in online marketplaces. Additional consumer protections are necessary to enhance public trust in the Internet. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. The curr_chunk defines an "electronic marketplace" as an enterprise that brings together offers, bids, or orders of multiple participants through electronic means accessible to the general public. An electronic marketplace is defined as an enterprise that brings together offers, bids, or orders of multiple participants through electronic means accessible to the general public. Exclusions from this definition include securities exchanges, national securities associations, contract markets, derivative transaction execution facilities, and marketplaces operated by a single vendor for retail transactions. An electronic marketplace is defined as an enterprise that brings together offers, bids, or orders of multiple participants through electronic means accessible to the general public. Exclusions from this definition include securities exchanges, national securities associations, contract markets, derivative transaction execution facilities, and marketplaces operated by a single vendor for retail transactions. Marketplaces with an annual transaction volume less than $10,000,000 may be excluded based on factors like transaction volume, number of transactions, or market participants over time. A marketplace is not considered restricted to licensed specialists just because it requires participants from the general public. An electronic marketplace requires participants to register and disclose information. The term "Commission" refers to the Federal Trade Commission. An "affiliate" is any company that is directly or indirectly controlled by another company. SEC. 3. ELECTRONIC MARKETPLACE DISCLOSURE REGULATIONS. The Commission will prescribe rules to prohibit unfair and deceptive acts in electronic marketplaces by requiring disclosure of ownership and financial arrangements with market participants. The regulation will require clear and conspicuous disclosure of ownership and financial arrangements in electronic marketplaces, including special privileges for some participants. The Commission will prescribe regulations for clear and accessible disclosure of ownership and financial arrangements in electronic marketplaces, with updates required quarterly and no need to disclose actual contracts with market participants. Regulatory authority includes rulemaking and issuance of regulations within 6 months of enactment. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT. The Act and regulations will be enforced by the Commission under the Federal Trade Commission Act.
